lines.text: [the boys are switching clothes - the prince holds up one of Tom's tattered garments]
Are there in any vermin in this?
So few you'll hardly notice them at all, your highness.
[Miles has taken the Prince to his home for the night]
I'm hungry. What have you to tempt my appetite?
Well, now, that depends on what didn't tempt the mices.
Mice?
Oh, yes. I had to fatten them all up. You see the, uh, cat threatened to leave.
You're making a joke.
The humor of being short of rations, my small friend, has always escaped me.
Then you're poor?
Would you believe it? I am.
[John and Hugo have brought the prince - thinking he's Tom - to help them steal from the inn]
if ya don't do like you've been told, we'll put climes on ya! Twenty of 'em! Ya know what climes are?
[the prince shakes his head, 'no']
Tell him, Hugo.

They're little bandages, with a bit o' paste on 'em, made o' soap and quicklime and rust off old iron. And when ya takes 'em off there's the nastiest looking sore that ever made a citizen sick. Sores that don't get well, but spread like a disease.
No... no... I'll steal.
Let's get at it then.
[Miles sits down to share the supper]
Would you sit in the presence of your king?
Now, see here, my lad!
I will no longer tolerate your manner.

[humoring him]
I ask your pardon, your majesty, but after that chase we led them it would be good to sit down.
Perhaps.
[Miles sits]
No! Custom must be preserved - you will stand.
[Miles stands and then leans against the wall, getting annoyed as the prince finishes the supper]
I was very hungry. Feel better now.
I'm gratified, your majesty.
Come to think of it, I'm under obligation to you in many ways. Your service demands rich reward.
Oh, a mere nothing, your majesty.
You may have any reward you wish... name it.
The, uh, privilege of sitting in your majesty's presence.
Advance, fellow, and give me your sword.

[gives his sword to the prince]
Did you find the mutton tough, sire?
Kneel.
[the prince lays the sword on Miles' shoulder]
While England remains - and the crown continues - you and your heirs, forever, may sit in the presence of the majesty of England.
[he taps the sword on Miles' shoulder]
Arise, Sir Miles Hendon.
For pity sake, sit down.
Thank you, your majesty.
[Tom - as the prince - is signing documents]
Please, sir, how much longer must I do this?
This is the last, sire.

[starts to read the document]
"Authorizes an increased tax on windows..." Do you mean to say we have a tax on windows?
May I suggest that your majesty cease troubling himself about...
But I'm head of the government. It's my job to be troubled about these things. And I think a tax on windows is cruel... unjust.
The royal treasury is empty, sire. Every means of replenishing it must be taken.

Yes... but windows. Don't you see when poor people are sick, windows are the only outside they have? Why they wouldn't have anything nice to look at if it weren't for windows. And, besides... that's taxing sunshine and light, which don't belong to us at all, but to God.
Who are you, fellow?
Miles Hendon, Your Majesty.
Your name is not familiar. What is your trade?
Soldiering, sire.
In my service?
In the service of anyone who can afford enemies.
Soldier of fortune. Strange profession.

Well, of the three of them for a gentleman without means I think it's the most amusing. Cheating at cards means associating with dull people. Preaching the gospel means wearing one of those funny hats.
